shock.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: if something that happens is a shock, you did not expect it, and it makes you feel very surprised, and usually upset
shock.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: It was a real shock to hear that the factory would have to close.
it was a shock to find/discover etc that
The news of his death came as a great shock to everyone.
shock.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the feeling of surprise and disbelief you have when something very unexpected happens, especially something bad or frightening
shock.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She was shaking with shock and humiliation.
Mom’s never really gotten over the shock of Dad’s death.
shock.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a medical condition in which someone looks pale and their heart and lungs are not working correctly, usually after a sudden very unpleasant experience
shock.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: He was bleeding from the head and suffering from shock.
He is clearly in a state of shock.
The tanker driver was treated for shock and released.
shock.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a sudden unexpected change which threatens the economic situation, way of life, or traditions of a group of people – used especially in news reports
shock.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: violent shaking caused for example by an explosion or earthquake
shock.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: The shock was felt miles away.
shock.translation[0].note_box[0].section: a big/great shock
It was a great shock to find out he had been lying.
a terrible/awful shock
Her death was a terrible shock to everyone.
a complete/total shock
No one expected the factory to close – it was a complete shock.
a nasty shock
Come and sit down. You’ve had a nasty shock.
a rude shock
Shopping for food in Miyako brought a rude shock. The prices were breathtaking.
get/have a shock
I got a shock when I saw how thin he had become.
give somebody a shock
Oh, you gave me quite a shock.
get over/recover from a shock
He hasn’t got over the shock of losing his job yet.
die of shock
I nearly died of shock when I saw Helen at the door.
come as a shock
The collapse of the company came as a shock to us all.
be a bit of a shock
I wasn’t expecting to win, so it was a bit of a shock.
be a shock to the system
Having to work full-time again was quite a shock to the system.
be in for a shock
Anyone who thinks that bringing up children is easy is in for a shock.
be in a state of shock
Eva left the room in a state of shock.
get the shock of your life
He got the shock of his life when he found out who I was.
shock.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to make someone feel very surprised and upset, and unable to believe what has happened
shock.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The hatred in her voice shocked him.
They had been shocked to hear that the hospital was closing down.
shock somebody to hear/learn/discover etc that
It shocked me to think how close we had come to being killed.
She was shocked into action by the desperate situation in the orphanages.
shock.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to make someone feel very offended, by talking or behaving in an immoral or socially unacceptable way
shock.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: He seems to enjoy shocking people.
Just ignore the bad language – they only do it to shock.
shock.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: very surprising – used especially in news reports
